definition:
The Bargmann transform of a function, $f$, is a linear map
$B: X(\mathbb{R}) \to Y(\mathbb{C})$ defined by

$$B f(z)=\sqrt{2} \int_\mathbb{R} f(t)  \hskip2pt e^{2\pi t z-\pi t^2 - \frac{\pi}{2} z^2}\, dt$$

The Bargmann transform on $L^2(\mathbb{R})$,
$B: L^2(\mathbb{R}) \to \mathcal{F}^2(\mathbb{C})$, is a unitary
transformation. Here $\mathcal{F}^2(\mathbb{C})$ is the Fock space.
